stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on the new “Bowser Protest” construction-site stage: adding coins, polishing crane colours, replacing the Bowser switch model, and solving an ‘infinite ocean’ background while constantly testing N64 performance and stability.

development_findings.summary: The level currently holds ~8 000 polygons, no render areas and no back-face culling; worst-case speed is ~22 FPS on real N64 hardware. Adding culling, triangle sorting and collision maps is expected to raise speed by 5–6 FPS.
development_findings.quote: This is an 8000-polygon level. No render areas. Sorting the triangles will also give us a big performance boost.

development_findings.summary: By mistake the stage was exported with F3D microcode instead of F3DEX2, doubling vertex loads and triangle commands; despite that it still reached 30 FPS, indicating large optimisation headroom.
development_findings.quote: We had twice the vertex loads, twice the triangle commands… and it still ran fine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is distributing extra coin objects to make the arena feel ‘alive’, but one vertical coin formation caused memory corruption and camera render bugs, suggesting a deeper object-pool or display-list issue.
development_findings.quote: The only thing I changed was add a bunch of coin formations and then suddenly this started happening.

development_findings.summary: Crane cabins now use individual colours; black looked poor, orange too saturated. Settled on a dark Bowser-themed hue suggested by Lilaa.
The classic Bowser floor switch had UV mis-alignment (Nintendo’s map). Biobak supplied a new 1 336-poly model (down from ~4 000) with a single RGBA texture, adopted as the definitive version.
development_findings.quote: This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one. Very, very nice.

development_findings.summary: Wiseguy’s “Matrix Stack Fix” is mandatory for world-space directional lighting; otherwise lights are transformed by the camera.
development_findings.quote: If you put a light source into the original game, your light source is gonna be transformed by the camera.

development_findings.summary: A new visual solution for the ocean background: a curved 3-D water plane that follows 0.85–0.9 of camera translation, blended into fog with an oil-tinted gradient; NF-background attempts were rejected because of N64 culling limits.
development_findings.quote: I think an NBG doesn’t work if the elements in your level are touching the skybox. We curved the ocean plane instead.

development_findings.summary: NEMU64 was recently revived; it now offers GDB debugging and accurate cache emulation, becoming Kaze’s primary emulator for real-time debugging.
development_findings.quote: A new emulator dropped called NEMU64… you can debug everything with it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze still holds a full-time C/C++ programming job, which restricts hack development time.
context_findings.quote: I have a full-time job on the side, so that’s why I don’t have too much time.

context_findings.summary: He jokes about monetising Twitter impressions and refuses to pay for Twitter Blue unless it covers his bills.
context_findings.quote: We’re gonna get Twitter Blue and it’s gonna pay my bills and I’m never gonna pay for Twitter Blue again.

context_findings.summary: A merch company offered to print custom N64 boxes and manuals; Kaze wants to package empty boxes (legal) and separate ROMs (e.g., OST-only) as revenue streams and possibly launch a ROM-making company, hiring contributors and paying musicians.
context_findings.quote: Dude, when I sell RTYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM and it’d be legal… maybe I’m gonna start hiring people.

context_findings.summary: Personal: self-described ‘vampire’ indoors, jokes about dying in the sun and being the ‘whitest man alive’.

biobak.summary: Supplied a lower-poly, UV-fixed Bowser switch model and texture; also drove the horizon-gradient concept for the ocean background.

zeina.summary: Was scheduled to finish an animation for a yet-unnamed character (‘the guy here’) but was absent this session.
zeina.quote: Unfortunately Zeina's gone today, otherwise she maybe would have finished the animation for the guy here.

key_stories.title: The Mis-exported Level
key_stories.summary: Kaze unknowingly exported the entire stage with the slower F3D microcode. Only after noticing exceptionally high command counts did he realise the error.
key_stories.challenge: Unexpectedly high vertex load yet acceptable framerate suggested something was wrong.
key_stories.process: Investigated export settings; discovered the model was using F3D instead of F3DEX2.
key_stories.outcome: Re-exporting will halve command load, giving free performance headroom.
key_stories.key_quote: I was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DEX2… we had twice the vertex loads and it still ran fine.

key_stories.title: Bowser Switch Make-over
key_stories.summary: The classic Bowser floor switch looked off—its UVs were mis-aligned. Community discussion blamed Kaze before he discovered Nintendo’s original mapping was at fault.
key_stories.challenge: Switch texture appeared off-centre and low-poly.
key_stories.process: Verified UV map, confirmed Nintendo’s error, then accepted Biobak’s redesigned model.
key_stories.outcome: New switch is sharper, accurate and uses one third of the polygons.
key_stories.key_quote: Don’t blame Nintendo just yet… oh, this is Nintendo’s UV map, not me.

key_stories.title: Building an Infinite Ocean
key_stories.summary: Kaze tried multiple background techniques to convey endless sea. NF backgrounds failed due to hardware clip distance. After hours of trial, he devised a moving, curved water plane blended with fog.
key_stories.challenge: Make the sea look vast without breaking N64 culling limits.
key_stories.process: Tested NF BG, adjusted fog, experimented with curved geometry tied to camera translation, colour-graded horizon.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on 3-D plane at 0.85 camera factor plus oil-red gradient—‘about as good as we're gonna get’.
key_stories.key_quote: An NBG doesn’t work if the elements in your level are touching the background… this curved plane finally works.
